summary.p: Single folio, Shelfmark: HC.MS.03101, Writing surface: parchment, Text: 18:1-21, Lines per page: 13, Dimensions: 178 x 255 mm; with integrations 227 x 293. Sister leaves: There are no sister leaves currently known from this Qur’ān.

support.p: Codicology and Illumination: The recto is the hair side of the parchment and the verso is the flesh side. Fifth verse divisions are marked with a small gold letter hāʾ (representing 5 in the abjad system). Tenth verse divisions are marked with an illuminated roundel in gold, green and brown containing the exact verse count written in gold kūfī script (ductus D.I/D.II). On this folio the relevant verse counts are ten and twenty.

summary.p: Script style: kūfī, Ductus: Main Qur’ānic Text: D.Vc with elements of D.Vb; Incidentals (gold sura heading of Sura 018): D.I/D.II; Diacritics: Letter-pointing (ʾiʿǧām): diagonal dashes in brown ink (original); Vocalisation (taškīl): red and green dots. Estimated date of production: 10th century; François Déroche notes cautiously that a script close to D.Vc is used in a waqf inscription dated 298/911 (Déroche 1992, p. 42), and Fraser notes that certain letter forms are closer to New Style scripts (Fraser and Kwiatkowski 2006, pp. 52-57, where further discussion of this script can be found). Both authors suggest a tenth-century origin for Qur’āns written in this script. In the main Qur’ānic text, all letters are D.Vc except the tā’/ẓā’. There are two forms of the letter tā’/ẓā’. In one, the ascender rises vertically, as in D.Vc, whereas in the other the ascender rises at an oblique angle and curves over at the top, which is the form of tā’/ẓā’ used in D.Vb. The overlapping nature of these two ductae is shown by other shared features. For example, other manuscripts written in D.Vc employ two forms of the final nūn, one the angular form found in D.Vb and the other the rounded form of D.Vc (see (Fraser and Kwiatkowski 2006, p. 52, fig. 5, p. 53 main illustration). The oblique curved form of tā’/ẓā’ found on the present folio is also frequently found in New Style scripts of the tenth century and later (e.g., inter alia, a copy of the Mawaqif dated 344/956, see George 2010, p. 126, fig. 73; the "Muṣḥaf al-Hāḍinah Qur’ān" ("Qurʾān of the Nurse"), made at Qayrawan in 1019-20, see Fraser and Kwiatkowski 2006, p. 60), and is thus an indication of a transitional aspect in the script D.Vc. The same applies to the inward-curving verticals of the lām-ʾalif, which are found in kūfī D.Vb (e.g. the Isfahan Qur’ān of 383/993, see Déroche 1992, no.83, pp. 154-5, although not on the present leaf). It therefore seems that D.Vb and D.Vc represent a style and a period when the influence of New Style scripts was beginning to impact on the established kūfī styles. This would in turn accord with the probability that this script was in use in the tenth century. There is no use of mašq (“horizontal stretching of the letter forms”) and the length of each letter is very regular.
